awd_titl_txt: Power and Energy Conference at Illinois March 2022 (PECI)
awd_abstract_narration:
This travel grant will be used for offsetting the cost of attendees participating at the 13th Annual Power and Energy Conference at Illinois (PECI). Beginning in 2010, PECI is the oldest annual, student-run IEEE international conference about power and energy technology. The conference is organized by the IEEE PES/PELS/IAS Joint Graduate Student Chapter at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and is advised by faculty in the Power and Energy area of the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. The conference will take place on March 10-11th, 2022 at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. PECI has become a perfect place in the Midwest for industry, academic researchers, and students to discuss future power and energy topics such as renewable energy, machines for electric transportation, smart grid reliability, security of cyber physical systems, and power electronics for emerging technologies. The travel funding for PECI will support underrepresented students such as those from primarily undergraduate or minority institutions, and the expected number of sponsored students is approximately 20-30. Students who apply for funding will be encouraged to present either a poster or paper and will compete for Best Paper and Best Poster Awards. 

The travel funding for PECI 2022 will help introduce students to innovative power-focused technologies in both the academic and industry sectors, in fields such as machines, power systems, power electronics and entrepreneurship. This will advance the power engineering community by fostering discussion between the leaders of tomorrow and current academic and industry professionals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
PECI conferences have a history of giving students their first opportunity at research presentations.  Also, for many of the undergraduate attendees, this is their first exposure to a professional conference and many of the research challenges facing the power and energy industry. Furthermore, PECI encourages discussion of systematic integration of research and teaching. Based on recent history of PECI conferences, the NSF support has significantly increased the participation of women and minorities in PECI. In 2022, 81.25% of these participants receiving NSF support were women or minorities. In the future, the PECI committee hopes to continue to increase the participation of women and minorities as well as students from schools that do not offer a Ph.D. program.

Support from NSF for student travel to PECI in 2022 enabled 16 participants from 8 different universities to learn from the conference experience by covering their registration, accommodation expenses and/or travel to and from the conference. Students attended from: Arizona State University, Western Michigan University, Rose-Hulman University, University of Washington, St. Louis University, Purdue, University of Connecticut and Texas A&M University. Feedback from the students who received NSF travel support was extremely positive with many indicating that they were planning to submit papers or posters for PECI in 2023.

PECI is unique in its focus on students preparing and presenting technical papers and posters as well as learning about careers in power and energy STEM fields. This conference provides a unique opportunity for NSF to interact with and promote interaction among students, academia and the power industry to promote and discuss NSF?s vision of technical challenges in power and energy systems, including technical, societal and economic aspects; and more broadly in cyber-physical (CPS) systems, renewable energy, and more-electric transportation. PECI is also a venue to an exciting student paper and poster competition for identifying and fostering high quality research performed by students.  In summary, the intellectual merit of PECI are the student focused nature of the conference, from the student led steering committee to all technical and presentations, and the high-quality publications and posters from student attendees.        

In addition to technical presentations from 30 conference paper submissions, conference attendees had the opportunity to learn about the future of power and energy technology through an undergraduate poster session, five keynote presentations, one industry demo booth, presentations by industry partners and technology companies, panels on new and exciting technical developments, and a tour of the local POETS research facility. Centering on the theme, ?Power Today, Change Tomorrow? the 2022 PECI conference included:

  • Five inspirational keynote presentations on: Artificial Intelligence in Modern Power Systems (Prof. Ganesh Kumar Venayagamoorthy, Clemson University), Challenges and Opportunities in Automotive Power Electronics (Dr. Pradeep S. Shenoy, Texas Instruments), Burning Issues: Modeling Risk of Wildfire Ignitions and Power Outages in the Electric Grid (Prof. Line Roald, University of Wisconsin) , Electrical Machines Used in Offshore Wind Generators (Dr. David Torrey, GE Research), and Electrical and Electronic Hardware Trends in Aviation (Kristina Korosi, Meggitt).
  • A 3D Printer Demo by Nano Dimension DragonFly PCB.
  • Thirty technical paper presentations and five posters.
  • A tour of the newly renovated Electrical and Computer Engineering Building student research labs at UIUC.
  • Attendees also had the opportunity to attend a PELS Young Professionals Event as part of an engaging social event. The social event was well attended, with 30 attendees interacting with peers and industry leaders.
  • Panel discussion about Power Electronics in Renewable Energy Systems.

 


Last Modified: 08/23/2022
Modified by: Kiruba Haran
